article:
made up of a collection of hyphae; a key part in the process of saprotrophic
 nutrition, it is used for the intake of organic matter through its cell wall.
 The network of hyphae is referred to as a mycelium, which is fundamental to
 fungal nutrition.]] 'Saprotrophic nutrition' () is a process of
 chemoheterotrophic extracellular digestion involved in the processing of dead
 or decayed organic matter. It occurs in saprotrophs or heterotrophs, and is
 most often associated with fungi, for example [[Mucor]] and [[Rhizopus]]. The
 process is most often facilitated through the active transport of such
 materials through endocytosis within the internal mycelium and its constituent
 hyphae. Advanced biology principles, p
 296âstates the purpose of saprotrophs and their internal nutrition, as well as
 the main two types of fungi that are most often referred to, as well as
 describes, visually, the process of saprotrophic nutrition through a diagram of
 hyphae, referring to the Rhizobium on damp, stale whole-meal bread or rotting
 fruit.
